intro: Comastoma boreale, commonly known as the northern puccoon, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the northern regions of North America. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its basal rosette of lanceolate, hairy leaves. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to red, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands or along stream banks. Comastoma boreale is valued for its ornamental appeal and its role in supporting local pollinators.
